service_territory.description: MISO operates in Arkansas through the Entergy Arkansas service territory. Arkansas is part of MISO South region and is located in Local Resource Zone 8 (LRZ 8). MISO has a control center in Little Rock, Arkansas.
utilities: Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corporation (dual MISO/SPP member)
service_territory.notes: Arkansas became part of MISO when Entergy joined in December 2013. MISO operates one of its three control centers in Little Rock, Arkansas. Arkansas is examining opportunities for aggregated demand response under Grid Modernization proceedings at the Arkansas Public Service Commission.

regulatory_context.arkansas_statute: Arkansas law prohibits the marketing or selling of demand response into wholesale electricity markets by aggregators of retail customers or retail customers unless the Arkansas Public Service Commission determines it is in the public interest.
regulatory_context.statute_reference: Arkansas Code Title 23-18-1004 (Regulation of Electric Demand Response Act)
regulatory_context.current_status: Arkansas Public Service Commission is examining Grid Modernization and distributed energy resources including demand response programs. Arkansas is positioned to potentially allow third-party aggregators similar to Illinois.

programs.description: Emergency demand response resource that reduces load during grid emergencies to prevent rolling blackouts. LMRs are part of MISO's resource adequacy framework and are obligated to respond during emergency events. LMRs serve dual purposes - planning resources for reserve margin requirements and emergency resources for capacity emergencies.

requirements: Legal title and ability to control the resource
eligibility.battery_suitability: Battery energy storage systems are eligible as Behind-the-Meter Generation (BTMG) for LMR participation. Non-injecting behind-the-meter battery storage can participate in demand response programs.

notification_and_response.historical_note: MISO has never called upon EDRs in its history, indicating rare emergency dispatch events

capacity_credits.description: Capacity credits based on notification time requirements
capacity_credits.accreditation_basis: Peak demand periods: June-August, 2:00 PM - 6:00 PM
capacity_credits.maximum_notification_time: 6 hours or less (reduced from 12 hours starting PY 2023-2024)

compensation.primary_payment: Zonal Resource Credits (ZRCs) from Planning Resource Auction

recent_capacity_prices_arkansas.annual_price_mw_day: not available - zone-specific data not published
recent_capacity_prices_arkansas.notes: Historical reference shows LRZ 8 cleared at $4.75/MW-day in one auction
First auction with MISO's seasonal framework. Most zones cleared at $10/MW-day summer, except Zone 9 (Louisiana) at $60/MW-day fall
All zones except Missouri. Capacity prices for summer and spring roughly tripled. MISO South surplus held at 1,744 MW.
First year using Reliability-Based Demand Curve (RBDC). Dramatic price increase from $30/MW-day to $666.50/MW-day summer. 9,000 MW of DR cleared (all offered).

compensation.energy_market_participation: Not allowed for LMRs - emergency response only
compensation.must_offer_description: LMRs must make capacity available to Day-Ahead market or Resource Adequacy Construct mechanisms if registered for capacity

performance_requirements.testing_threshold: Demonstrate at least 50% of registered capability
testing_methods: Actual deployment during MISO emergency event
performance_requirements.testing_reforms: All new LMRs Type I will undergo initial testing; LMR Type II deployment during emergency counts as test
performance_requirements.baseline_verification: Third-party auditor verification required if no state/retail regulatory accreditation
performance_requirements.meter_data_requirements: Hourly meter data for 15 days before and 15 days after event, submitted within 53 calendar days
performance_requirements.performance_measurement: Firm Service Level (FSL) - predetermined load reduction target
baseline_methodologies: Firm Service Level (FSL) - reducing to specified electricity demand level
Meter Before/Meter After - measuring consumption over prescribed period
Baseline Type-II - statistical sampling for aggregated resources without interval metering
performance_requirements.performance_issues_identified: Independent Market Monitor found up to 25% of DR resources submit mock tests instead of real tests

penalties.significance: Significantly higher financial consequences for non-performance. VOLL increase makes reliable performance essential for participants.

steps: Register as Market Participant with MISO
Provide documentation of load reduction capabilities
Obtain Load Serving Entity (LSE) and Load Balancing Area (LBA) confirmation
Obtain RERRA (Regional Entities for Resource Reliability Assessment) approval
Submit to Planning Resource Auction or Fixed Resource Adequacy Plan (FRAP)
registration_process.online_registration: MISO Online Registration tool required for all market participants
registration_process.use_elemental_pricing_nodes: Required for PY 2025-2026 auction registration onwards
registration_process.arkansas_specific_note: Arkansas law requires Arkansas Public Service Commission determination that wholesale DR participation is in public interest

reform_timeline.milestone: FERC Tariff filing for LMR accreditation reforms
MISO filed proposed LMR changes with FERC (Docket No. ER25-1729-000)
FERC filing to eliminate dual LMR/EDR registration
Last year for dual LMR/EDR registration
Full implementation of LMR Type I/II reforms

program_changes.eliminating_dual_registration: LMRs can no longer be registered as Emergency Demand Response (EDR) starting PY 2026-2027

new_lmr_types.deployment_trigger: Energy Emergency Alerts and Warnings leading up to emergency event

program_changes.maximum_notification_reduction: Maximum notification time reduced from 12 hours to 6 hours starting PY 2023-2024

programs.program_type: Energy and Ancillary Services Market Participation
programs.market_type: Wholesale energy and operating reserves markets
programs.description: Economic demand response that participates in MISO's Day-Ahead and Real-Time energy markets, as well as ancillary services markets. DRRs provide grid flexibility during normal operations and are dispatched based on economic offers. Resources are treated as supply resources and must follow market dispatch instructions.

drr_types.description: Customer programs like industrial interruptible load, provides energy or contingency reserve through physical load interruption
ancillary_services_not_allowed: Regulating Reserves (frequency responsive nature requires telemetry)
drr_types.performance_issues: IMM evaluation found more than 40% of DRR Type I resources did not perform adequately in spinning reserve deployments (213 deployments across 22 event days in 2023-24)

drr_types.description: Behind-the-meter generators or highly controllable load, can receive electronic dispatch instructions and follow 5-minute setpoints. Treated as if it were a traditional generator.
drr_types.regulation_service_requirements: Must provide both REG UP and REG DOWN service and respond to AGC instructions within four seconds
drr_types.battery_suitability: Excellent suitability for battery storage systems due to fast response, telemetry capabilities, and continuous variable output

eligibility.minimum_capacity_drr: No specified minimum for DRR itself
eligibility.minimum_for_aggregator: 1 MW+ enrolled demand to register with demand response aggregator
requirements: Ability to reduce electricity consumption or increase behind-the-meter generation
Type II must follow 5-minute dispatch instructions
Type II must provide telemetered output data
eligibility.battery_storage_eligibility: Non-injecting behind-the-meter battery storage may participate as Demand Response in MISO. Battery storage used to reduce grid consumption (charging less or discharging to offset load) qualifies for DR participation.
eligibility.battery_storage_requirements: For behind-the-meter configurations, Market Participant must report and telemeter only wholesale volumes of charge/discharge. Requires Attachment HHH attestation that coordination with Distribution Companies and Retail Regulators completed.

energy_market_participation.day_ahead_market: Must offer if cleared Planning Resource Auction
energy_market_participation.payment_structure: Locational Marginal Price (LMP) if deployment is economically beneficial

net_benefits_price_threshold.description: DRR only paid if LMP exceeds NBPT
net_benefits_price_threshold.nbpt_determination: Established monthly by MISO and released ahead
net_benefits_price_threshold.nbpt_purpose: Ensures benefits from reduced LMP exceed cost of dispatching DRR. Determines when DR is deemed helpful to grid by reducing a MW instead of generator supplying a MW.
net_benefits_price_threshold.recent_proposal: MISO proposing offer floor at NBPT level to prevent gaming and market manipulation (Docket No. ER25-1729-000)
net_benefits_price_threshold.ferc_order_745_purpose: Determine when DR eligible to receive full LMP payment rather than reduced payment

energy_market_participation.co_optimization: Energy and ancillary services markets are co-optimized in market clearing

compensation.capacity_market: Optional - DRR may register as Capacity Resource OR LMR, but not both
compensation.energy_payment: LMP for demand reduction when LMP > NBPT
compensation.ancillary_services_payment: Market clearing price for reserves services
compensation.payment_condition: Only paid if deployment found beneficial to grid
compensation.payment_frequency: Based on actual deployment and capacity reservation

steps: Register as Market Participant with MISO
Submit Certification of Relationships for DRRs
Potential Aggregator of Retail Customers (ARC) Certificate
For Type II: Install telemetry and control systems
Obtain LSE/LBA confirmation and RERRA approval
For battery storage: Submit Attachment HHH attestation of Distribution Company and Retail Regulator coordination
registration_process.registration_manual: BPM-001 Market Registration, BPM-026 Demand Response Business Practices
registration_process.electric_storage_requirements: Must meet all measurement requirements in Tariff Section 38.2.5.e and Market Settlements BPM-005 through direct metering or functional equivalent

performance_requirements.dispatch_compliance: Must respond to MISO Dispatch, Setpoint, or Scheduling Instructions
performance_requirements.baseline_calculation: Load reduction measured from baseline load level using CBL methodologies
performance_requirements.tariff_violation: Failure to respond constitutes Tariff violation
performance_requirements.ancillary_services_requirements: Must deliver energy to grid within prescribed time limit specific to Operating Reserve product offered

program_status.note: Low participation compared to LMR programs. Performance concerns identified by Independent Market Monitor.

programs.description: Demand response participation in MISO's operating reserves market to stabilize grid during unexpected system disruptions. Resources provide quick response for grid reliability. Available 24x7x365 year-round.

requirements: Curtailable load of at least 1 MW
Telemetry capability (for DRR Type II participation)
eligibility.battery_suitability: Excellent suitability for battery storage systems due to fast response capability, especially for DRR Type II participation in all reserve products including Regulating Reserves

regulating_reserves.agc_requirements: Must respond to AGC instructions within four seconds
regulating_reserves.must_provide_both: REG UP and REG DOWN service
regulating_reserves.battery_suitability: Excellent for battery storage - requires continuous variable output and fast response

spinning_reserves.eligible_resources: DRR Type I and Type II
spinning_reserves.performance_note: Over 40% of DRR Type I resources did not perform adequately in 2023-24

supplemental_reserves.eligible_resources: DRR Type I and Type II

ramp_capability.description: Ability to increase/decrease output to follow load ramps

compensation.payment_basis: Market clearing price for specific reserve product
compensation.co_optimization: Energy and ancillary services markets are co-optimized
compensation.payment_frequency: Based on actual deployment and capacity reservation

sources: https://cdn.misoenergy.org/Fact Sheet - MISO Market Participation Overview632546.pdf

programs.program_name: Emergency Demand Response (EDR) - Being Phased Out
programs.description: Emergency demand response resources that can reduce load or operate backup generation during grid emergencies. This program is being eliminated with dual LMR/EDR registration ending after PY 2025-2026. MISO has never called upon EDRs in its history.

phase_out_timeline.reason: Consolidating to two programs (DRR and LMR) for simplification. EDR program complexity and lack of historical deployment.

current_requirements.capability: Reduce load or operate backup generation during emergencies
current_requirements.cross_registration_note: Approximately 50% of LMRs were cross-registered as EDRs

transition_plan.description: Resources currently registered as both LMR and EDR must choose one program after PY 2025-2026

planning_resource_auction.description: Annual capacity auction for resource adequacy
planning_resource_auction.recent_trends: Significant price increases due to declining reserve margins and generator retirements. Summer 2025/26 prices jumped from $30/MW-day to $666.50/MW-day.
planning_resource_auction.demand_response_cleared: 9,000 MW of DR cleared in 2025/26 auction (all offered DR capacity was accepted)
planning_resource_auction.rbdc_implementation: First year using Reliability-Based Demand Curve (RBDC) instead of vertical demand curve for PY 2025-2026

energy_markets.day_ahead_market: Forward energy market cleared day before delivery
energy_markets.real_time_market: Spot energy market for actual delivery, 5-minute dispatch
energy_markets.co_optimization: Energy and ancillary services co-optimized in market clearing
energy_markets.dispatch_algorithms: Security Constrained Unit Commitment (SCUC) and Security Constrained Economic Dispatch (SCED)

transmission_zones.lrz_purpose: Address congestion limiting resource deliverability and define capacity benefits
transmission_zones.arkansas_zone_characteristics: Part of MISO South region with generally lower capacity prices than MISO North/Central except in PY 2025-2026 where all zones priced the same in summer

aggregation_and_third_party.aggregator_definition: Market Participant sponsoring DRRs, LMRs, and/or EDRs provided by end-use customers that the ARC does not serve at retail
aggregation_rules: LMRs may only be aggregated up to Load Zone CPNode level
End use customer account can only be registered by one Market Participant
Requires LSE and LBA confirmation for registration changes
aggregation_and_third_party.arkansas_regulatory_constraint: Arkansas law requires Arkansas Public Service Commission determination that wholesale DR participation is in public interest before aggregators can market or sell DR into wholesale markets
aggregation_and_third_party.arkansas_future_outlook: Arkansas positioned to be next Illinois among MISO states allowing third-party aggregators, per Grid Modernization proceedings

curtailment_service_providers.services: Engineers assess facilities to optimize DR participation and maximize earnings. Manages enrollment, measurement, verification, and payments.

curtailment_service_providers.description: Global leader in demand response. Manages entire process including enrollment, measurement, verification, and payments.

curtailment_service_providers.note: Active in MISO markets. Subject to $18M FERC settlement in 2024 for alleged DR rules violations.

contact_information.arkansas_control_center: Little Rock, Arkansas (one of three MISO control centers)

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Performance-based accreditation, shortened notification times (6 hours max), standardized testing
drivers: Increased grid uncertainty from renewable integration
25% of DR resources submit mock tests instead of real tests

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Simplification to two DR programs: DRR and LMR. EDR never deployed in MISO history.
major_reforms_2024_2025.impact: Resources must choose either capacity-focused (LMR) or energy-focused (DRR) participation. Approximately 50% of LMRs were cross-registered as EDRs.

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Prohibit DRR offers below Net Benefits Price Threshold to prevent gaming and market manipulation
major_reforms_2024_2025.purpose: Address market fraud and gaming concerns. Stakeholder support from Voltus and others.

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Non-performance penalties increased from 3×LMP to VOLL (now $10,000/MWh from $3,500/MWh)
major_reforms_2024_2025.impact: Significantly higher financial consequences for non-performance. Reliable performance now essential.

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Maximum LMR notification time reduced from 12 hours to 6 hours
major_reforms_2024_2025.impact: Resources requiring more than 6 hours notification no longer qualify for LMR capacity accreditation

major_reforms_2024_2025.description: Replaced vertical demand curve with reliability-focused pricing structure that reflects increasing capacity value as system approaches minimum adequacy targets
major_reforms_2024_2025.impact: Dramatic price increases. Summer capacity prices jumped from $30/MW-day to $666.50/MW-day.
major_reforms_2024_2025.purpose: More accurate price signals for resource adequacy

drivers: Generator retirements (3.3 GW in suspensions and retirements for 2025/26)

battery_storage_outlook.current_status: Energy storage not currently cost competitive in MISO and SPP
battery_storage_outlook.limitations: Battery discharge times insufficient for some applications
battery_storage_outlook.market_participation_status: RTO market participation rules and/or supporting software systems have been delayed
battery_storage_outlook.future_outlook: Arkansas PSC examining preparation for distributed energy resources including battery storage under Grid Modernization initiatives
battery_storage_outlook.dr_participation_suitability: Excellent suitability for DRR Type II and Operating Reserves due to fast response, telemetry, and continuous variable output capabilities

arkansas_specific_notes.miso_membership: Entergy Arkansas joined MISO in December 2013. Arkansas Electric Cooperative Corporation is dual MISO/SPP member.
arkansas_specific_notes.control_center: MISO operates one of its three control centers in Little Rock, Arkansas
arkansas_specific_notes.regulatory_environment: Arkansas statute restricts aggregator participation without Arkansas Public Service Commission approval determining public interest
arkansas_specific_notes.grid_modernization: Arkansas PSC examining DER integration including solar, battery storage, smart thermostats, energy efficiency, and demand response measures
arkansas_specific_notes.future_aggregation_outlook: Arkansas positioned to be next Illinois in MISO states allowing third-party aggregators
arkansas_specific_notes.capacity_market_performance: Arkansas (LRZ-8) part of MISO South which maintained stable 1,744 MW capacity surplus through 2024-2025, though reserve margins declining system-wide
arkansas_specific_notes.notable_enforcement: Big River Steel (Osceola, Arkansas) - $22M settlement for receiving MISO DR payments without cutting load (300 MW peak load facility). Entergy Arkansas served as market participant.

battery_energy_storage_suitability.overall_assessment: Excellent suitability for battery storage systems, particularly for DRR Type II and Operating Reserves programs

advantages: Capacity payments available ($212/MW-day annual average MISO South for PY 2025-2026)
disadvantages: Emergency-only dispatch, no energy market participation
Must meet 6-hour or less notification requirement
High non-performance penalties (VOLL × MW shortfall = $10,000/MWh × shortfall)

advantages: Can participate in all ancillary services markets (Regulating Reserves, Spinning Reserves, Supplemental Reserves, Ramp Capability)
Energy market participation at LMP when economically beneficial
Continuous variable output matches battery capabilities
Fast response capability aligns with battery strengths
Telemetry requirements easily met by modern battery systems
5-minute dispatch instructions compatible with battery response times
disadvantages: Telemetry and control system installation required
Must follow MISO Dispatch, Setpoint, and Scheduling Instructions
Only paid when LMP exceeds NBPT ($28-52/MWh)

eligible_products: Regulating Reserves (DRR Type II only) - responds to AGC within 4 seconds
Ramp Capability Products (DRR Type II only)
advantages: 10-20 dispatches per year provides revenue opportunities
10-minute notification time manageable for battery systems
Market clearing price compensation for reserve products
disadvantages: Requires 1 MW minimum capacity (higher than LMR 100 kW minimum)

battery_energy_storage_suitability.recommended_strategy: Battery storage systems in Arkansas should consider DRR Type II registration for Operating Reserves and energy market participation, potentially combined with LMR BTMG registration for capacity revenues. The combination provides: (1) Capacity revenues from LMR (~$212/MW-day annual average), (2) Energy market revenues from DRR when LMP > NBPT, (3) Ancillary services revenues from Operating Reserves market. Note: DRR and LMR cannot both be registered as Capacity Resources, but DRR can participate in energy and ancillary services markets without capacity registration.
battery_energy_storage_suitability.regulatory_considerations: Arkansas law requires Arkansas Public Service Commission determination that wholesale DR participation is in public interest. Battery developers should coordinate with Arkansas PSC regarding Grid Modernization proceedings and third-party aggregator participation rules.
